<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='8',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bg.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:04 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Strategic Realignment of Station Portfolio</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
We continue to examine our television station group portfolio in light
of the FCC&#146;s broadcast ownership rules&nbsp;adopted in 2003.&#160; For a summary of these rules, refer to <i>Ownership Matters,</i> discussed in the <i>Federal
Regulation of Television Broadcasting</i>.&#160; Our objective is to build our local
franchises in the markets we deem strategic.&#160;
We routinely review and conduct investigations of potential television
station acquisitions, dispositions and station swaps.&#160; At any given time, we may be in discussions
with one or more television station owners.&#160;
For more information related to station sales, see <i>Note 13.
Discontinued Operations</i>, in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial
Statements.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Investments.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;
As in the past, we continue to seek more ways to diversify our business
and return additional value to our shareholders.&#160; We carry investments in various companies
from many different industries including sign design and fabrication, security
alarm monitoring and bulk acquisition, software development, information
technology staffing and consulting and television transmitter
manufacturing.&#160; In addition, we invest in
various real estate ventures including developmental land and apartment and
shopping complexes.&#160; We also invest in
private equity and structure debt and mezzanine financing investment
funds.&#160; Currently our investment activity
represents a small portion of our overall operating results. &#160;We expect to continue to make investments in
non-broadcast assets as sound economic opportunities appear.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">FEDERAL REGULATION OF TELEVISION BROADCASTING</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
ownership, operation and sale of television stations are subject to the
jurisdiction of the FCC, which acts under the authority granted by the
Communications Act of 1934, as amended (Communications Act).&#160; Among other things, the FCC assigns frequency
bands for broadcasting; determines the particular frequencies, locations and
operating power of stations; issues, renews, revokes and modifies station
licenses; regulates equipment used by stations; adopts and implements
regulations and policies that directly or indirectly affect the ownership,
operation and employment practices of stations; and has the power to impose
penalties for violations of its rules&nbsp;or the Communications Act.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
following is a brief summary of certain provisions of the Communications Act,
the Telecommunications Act of 1996 (the 1996 Act) and specific FCC regulations
and policies.&#160; Reference should be made
to the Communications Act, the 1996 Act, FCC rules&nbsp;and the public notices
and rulings of the FCC for further information concerning the nature and extent
of federal regulation of broadcast stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">License Grant and Renewal</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Television
stations operate pursuant to broadcasting licenses that are granted by the FCC
for maximum terms of eight years and are subject to renewal upon application to
the FCC.&#160; During certain periods when
renewal applications are pending, petitions to deny license renewals can be
filed by interested parties, including members of the public.&#160; The FCC will generally grant a renewal
application if it finds:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">that the station has served the public interest, convenience and
necessity;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">that there have been no serious violations by the licensee of the
Communications Act or the rules&nbsp;and regulations of the FCC; and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">that there have been no other violations by the licensee of the
Communications Act or the rules&nbsp;and regulations of the FCC that, when
taken together, would constitute a pattern of misconduct.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All of
the stations that we currently own and operate or provide programming services
or sales services to, pursuant to LMAs or other agreements, are presently
operating under regular licenses, which expire as to each station on the dates
set forth under <i>Television Broadcasting</i>
above.&#160; Although renewal of a license is
granted in the vast majority of cases even when petitions to deny are filed,
there can be no assurance that the license of any station will be renewed.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2004, we filed with the FCC an application for the
license renewal of WBFF-TV in Baltimore, Maryland.&#160; Subsequently, an individual named Richard D&#146;Amato
filed a petition to deny the application.&#160;
In 2004, we also filed with the FCC applications for the license renewal
of television stations: WXLV-TV, Winston-Salem, North Carolina; WMYV-TV,
Greensboro, North Carolina; WLFL-TV, Raleigh/Durham, North Carolina; WRDC-TV,
Raleigh/Durham, North Carolina; WLOS-TV, Asheville, North Carolina and WMMP-TV,
Charleston, South Carolina.&#160; An
organization calling itself &#147;Free Press&#148; filed a petition to deny the renewal
applications of these stations and also the renewal applications of two other
stations in those markets, which we program pursuant to LMAs: WTAT-TV,
Charleston, South Carolina and WMYA-TV, Anderson, South Carolina.&#160; Several individuals and an organization named
&#147;Sinclair Media Watch&#148; also filed informal objections to the license renewal
applications of WLOS-TV and WMYA-TV, raising essentially the same arguments
presented in the Free Press petition.&#160;
The FCC is currently in the process of considering these renewal
applications and we believe the objections have no merit.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">9</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='9',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bg.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:04 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On October&nbsp;12,
2004, the FCC issued a Notice of Apparent Liability for Forfeiture (NAL) in the
amount of $7,000 per station to virtually every FOX station, including the 15
FOX affiliates presently licensed to us and the four FOX affiliates programmed
by us and one FOX affiliate we sold in 2005.&#160;
The NAL alleged that the stations broadcast indecent material contained
in an episode of a FOX network program that aired on April&nbsp;7, 2003.&#160; We, as well as other parties including the
FOX network, filed oppositions to the NAL.&#160;
That proceeding is still pending.&#160;
Although we cannot predict the outcome of that proceeding or the effect
of any adverse outcome on the stations&#146; license renewal applications, the FOX
network has agreed to indemnify its affiliates for the full amount of this
liability.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On July&nbsp;21,
2005, we filed with the FCC an application to acquire the license and
non-license television broadcast assets of WNAB-TV in Nashville,
Tennessee.&#160;&#160; The Rainbow/PUSH Coalition
(Rainbow/PUSH) filed a petition to deny that application and also requested
that the FCC initiate a hearing to investigate whether WNAB-TV was improperly
operated with WZTV-TV and WUXP-TV, two of our stations located in the same
market as WNAB-TV.&#160; The FCC is currently
in the process of considering the transfer of the broadcast license and we
believe the Rainbow/PUSH petition has no merit.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On August&nbsp;1,
2005, we filed applications with the FCC requesting renewal of the broadcast
licenses for WICS-TV and WICD-TV in Springfield/Champaign, Illinois.&#160; Subsequently, various viewers filed informal
objections requesting that the FCC deny these renewal applications.&#160; On September&nbsp;30, 2005, we filed an
application with the FCC for the renewal of the broadcast license for KGAN-TV
in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.&#160; On December&nbsp;28,
2005, an organization calling itself &#147;Iowans for Better Local Television&#148; filed
a petition to deny that application.&#160; The
FCC is currently in the process of considering these renewal applications and
we believe the objections and petitions requesting denial have no merit.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On August&nbsp;1, 2005, we filed applications with the
FCC requesting renewal of the broadcast licenses for WCGV-TV and WVTV-TV in
Milwaukee, Wisconsin.&#160; On November&nbsp;1,
2005, the Milwaukee Public Interest Media Coalition filed a petition with the
FCC to deny these renewal applications.&#160;
On June&nbsp;13, 2007, the Video Division of the FCC denied the petition
to deny, and subsequently, the Milwaukee Public Interest Media Coalition filed
a petition for reconsideration of that decision, which we opposed.&#160; The petition for reconsideration and the
renewal applications are currently pending.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On February&nbsp;27,
2006, an individual named James Pennino purportedly filed a petition to deny
the license renewal application of WUCW-TV in Minneapolis, Minnesota.&#160; Despite not having found any official record
of the filing, we opposed the petition and the renewal application is currently
pending.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Action
on many license renewal applications, including those we have filed, has been
delayed because of the pendency of complaints that programming aired by the
various networks contained indecent material and complaints regarding alleged
violations of sponsorship identification rules.&#160;
We cannot predict when the FCC will address these complaints and act on
the renewal applications.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Recent
actions by the FCC have also made it difficult for us to predict the impact on
our license renewals from allegations related to the airing of indecent
material that may arise in the ordinary course of our business.&#160; For example, on Veterans&#146; Day in November&nbsp;2004,
we preempted (did not air) &#147;Saving Private Ryan&#148;, a program that was aired
during ABC&#146;s network programming time.&#160;
We were concerned that since the program contained the use of the &#147;F&#148;
word (indecent material as defined by the FCC) airing the programming could
result in a fine or other negative consequences for one or more of our ABC
stations.&#160; In February&nbsp;2005, the FCC
dismissed all complaints filed against ABC stations regarding this
program.&#160; The FCC&#146;s decision justified
what some may consider indecent material as appropriate in the context of the
program.&#160; Although this ruling has
expanded the programming opportunities of our stations, it still leaves us at
risk because what might be determined as legitimate context by us may not be
deemed so by the FCC and the FCC will not rule&nbsp;beforehand as this may be
considered a restriction of free speech.&#160;
For example, in September&nbsp;2006, we preempted a CBS network
documentary on the events that happened on September&nbsp;11, 2001 because the
program contained what some have argued is indecent material and the FCC would
not provide, in advance of the airing of the documentary, any guidance on
whether that material was appropriate in the context of the program.&#160; The result of this is that we only know that &#147;Saving
Private Ryan&#148; and &#147;Schindler&#146;s List&#148; are allowed to be aired in their unedited
entirety under current FCC rulings.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">10</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bg.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:04 2008' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Ownership Matters</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">General</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The
Communications Act prohibits the assignment of a broadcast license or the
transfer of control of a broadcast license without the prior approval of the
FCC.&#160; In determining whether to permit
the assignment or transfer of control of, or the grant or renewal of, a
broadcast license, the FCC considers a number of factors pertaining to the
licensee, including compliance with various rules&nbsp;limiting common
ownership of media properties, the &#147;character&#148; of the licensee and those persons
holding &#147;attributable&#148; interests in that licensee and compliance with the
Communications Act&#146;s limitations on alien ownership.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To
obtain the FCC&#146;s prior consent to assign a broadcast license or transfer
control of a broadcast license, appropriate applications must be filed with the
FCC.&#160; If the application involves a &#147;substantial
change&#148; in ownership or control, the application must be placed on public
notice for a period of approximately 30 days during which petitions to deny the
application may be filed by interested parties, including members of the
public.&#160; If the application does not
involve a &#147;substantial change&#148; in ownership or control, it is a &#147;pro forma&#148;
application.&#160; The &#147;pro forma&#148; application
is not subject to petitions to deny or a mandatory waiting period, but is
nevertheless subject to having informal objections filed against it.&#160; If the FCC grants an assignment or transfer
application, interested parties have approximately 30 days from public notice
of the grant to seek reconsideration or review of the grant.&#160; Generally, parties that do not file initial
petitions to deny, or informal objections against the application, face
difficulty in seeking reconsideration or review of the grant.&#160; The FCC normally has an additional ten days
to set aside such grant on its own motion.&#160;
When passing on an assignment or transfer application, the FCC is
prohibited from considering whether the public interest might be served by an
assignment or transfer to any party other than the assignee or transferee specified
in the application.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
FCC generally applies its ownership limits to &#147;attributable&#148; interests held by
an individual, corporation, partnership or other association.&#160; In the case of corporations holding, or
through subsidiaries controlling, broadcast licenses, the interests of
officers, directors and those who, directly or indirectly, have the right to
vote 5% or more of the corporation&#146;s stock (or 20% or more of such stock in the
case of insurance companies, investment companies and bank trust departments
that are passive investors) are generally attributable.&#160; In August&nbsp;1999, the FCC revised its
attribution and multiple ownership rules&nbsp;and adopted the equity-debt-plus rule&nbsp;that
causes certain creditors or investors to be attributable owners of a station.&#160; Under this rule, a major programming supplier
(any programming supplier that provides more than 15% of the station&#146;s weekly
programming hours) or same-market media entity will be an attributable owner of
a station if the supplier or same-market media entity holds debt or equity, or
both, in the station that is greater than 33% of the value of the station&#146;s
total debt plus equity.&#160; For the purposes
of this rule, equity includes all stock, whether voting or non-voting, and
equity held by insulated limited partners in partnerships.&#160; Debt includes all liabilities whether
long-term or short-term.&#160; In addition,
LMAs are attributable where a licensee owns a television station and programs
more than 15% of another television station in the same market.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Communications
Act prohibits the issuance of a broadcast license to, or the holding of a
broadcast license by, any corporation of which more than 20% of the capital
stock is owned of record or voted by non-U. S. citizens or their
representatives or by a foreign government or a representative thereof, or by
any corporation organized under the laws of a foreign country (collectively,
aliens).&#160; The Communications Act also
authorizes the FCC, if the FCC determines that it would be in the public
interest, to prohibit the issuance of a broadcast license to, or the holding of
a broadcast license by, any corporation directly or indirectly controlled by
any other corporation of which more than 25% of the capital stock is owned of
record or voted by aliens.&#160; The FCC has
issued interpretations of existing law under which these restrictions in
modified form apply to other forms of business organizations, including
partnerships.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a
result of these provisions, the licenses granted to our subsidiaries by the FCC
could be revoked if, among other restrictions imposed by the FCC, more than 25%
of our stock were directly or indirectly owned or voted by aliens.&#160; Sinclair and its subsidiaries are domestic
corporations, and the members of the Smith family (who together hold approximately
82% of the common voting rights of Sinclair) are all United States
citizens.&#160; Our amended and restated
Articles of Incorporation (the Amended Certificate) contain limitations on
alien ownership and control that are substantially similar to those contained
in the Communications Act.&#160; Pursuant to
the Amended Certificate, we have the right to repurchase alien-owned shares at
their fair market value to the extent necessary, in the judgment of the Board
of Directors, to comply with the alien ownership restrictions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January&nbsp;2008,
the FCC released a Report and Order that, with the exception of the
newspaper/broadcast cross-ownership rule, essentially re-adopts the ownership rules&nbsp;the
FCC originally introduced in 1999 and has enforced since then.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The relevant
2008 ownership rules&nbsp;are as follows:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Radio/Television Cross-Ownership Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
The FCC&#146;s radio/television cross-ownership rule&nbsp;(the &#147;one to a
market&#148; rule) generally permits a party to own a combination of up to two
television stations and six radio stations in the same market, depending on the
number of independent media voices in the market.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">11</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='11',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Newspaper/Broadcast Cross-Ownership Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
The FCC&#146;s rule&nbsp;generally prohibits the common ownership of a radio
or television broadcast station and a daily newspaper in the same market.&#160; However, the FCC will presume that, in the
top 20 DMAs, it is not inconsistent with the public interest for one entity to
own a daily newspaper and a radio station or, under the following
circumstances, a daily newspaper and a television station: if (1)&nbsp;the
television station is not ranked among the top-four stations in the DMA and (2)&nbsp;at
least eight independent &#147;major media voices&#148; remain in the DMA.&#160; The FCC will presume that all other
newspaper/broadcast mergers are not in the public interest, but it will allow
applicants to seek a waiver and rebut this presumption by clear and convincing
evidence that, post-merger, the merged entity will increase the diversity of
independent news outlets and increase competition among independent news
sources in the relevant market.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Dual Network Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The four
major television networks, FOX, ABC, CBS and NBC, are prohibited, absent a
waiver, from merging with each other.&#160; In
May&nbsp;2001, the FCC amended its dual network rule&nbsp;to permit the four
major television networks to own, operate, maintain or control other television
networks, such as The CW or MyNetworkTV.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">National Ownership Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; As of 2004,
by statute, the national television viewing audience reach cap is 39%.&#160; Under this rule, where an individual or
entity has an attributable interest in more than one television station in a
market, the percentage of the national television viewing audience encompassed
within that market is only counted once.&#160;
Additionally, since historically, VHF stations (channels 2 through 13)
have shared a larger portion of the market than UHF stations (channels 14
through 69), only half of the households in the market area of any UHF station
are included when calculating an entity&#146;s national television viewing audience
(commonly referred to as the &#147;UHF discount&#148;). The FCC has initiated a
proceeding to assess whether it has authority to alter the UHF Discount.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All
but seven of the stations we own and operate, or to which we provide
programming services, are UHF.&#160; We reach
approximately 22% of U. S. television households or 12.3% taking into account
the FCC&#146;s UHF discount.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Local Television (Duopoly) Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
A party may own television stations in adjoining markets, even if there
is Grade B (discussed below) overlap between the two stations&#146; analog signals
and generally may own two stations in the same market:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">if there is no Grade B overlap between the stations; or</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">if the market containing both the stations will contain at least eight
independently owned full-power television stations post-merger (the &#147;eight
voices test&#148;) and not more than one station is among the top-four ranked
stations in the market.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In
addition, a party may request a waiver of the rule&nbsp;to acquire a second or
third station in the market if the station to be acquired is economically
distressed or not yet constructed and there is no party who does not own a
local television station who would purchase the station for a reasonable price.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There
are three grades of service for traditional analog television broadcasts, City
(strongest), Grade A and Grade B (least strong); and the signal decreases in
strength the further away the viewer is from the broadcast antenna tower.&#160; Generally, it is not as easy for viewers with
properly installed outdoor antennas to receive a Grade B signal, as it is to
receive a Grade A or City Grade signal.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Antitrust Regulation</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The
Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Federal Trade Commission have increased
their scrutiny of the television industry since the adoption of the 1996 Act
and have reviewed matters related to the concentration of ownership within
markets (including LMAs) even when ownership or the LMA in question is
permitted under the laws administered by the FCC or by FCC rules&nbsp;and
regulations.&#160; The DOJ takes the position
that an LMA entered into in anticipation of a station&#146;s acquisition with the
proposed buyer of the station constitutes a change in beneficial ownership of
the station which, if subject to filing under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Anti Trust
Improvements Act, cannot be implemented until the waiting period required by
that statute has ended or been terminated.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Expansion
of our broadcast operations on both a local and national level will continue to
be subject to the FCC&#146;s ownership rules&nbsp;and any changes the FCC or
Congress may adopt.&#160; At the same time,
any further relaxation of the FCC&#146;s ownership rules, which could occur if the rules&nbsp;adopted
in 2008 are declared unenforceable, may increase the level of competition in
one or more markets in which our stations are located, more specifically to the
extent that any of our competitors may have greater resources and thereby be in
a superior position to take advantage of such changes.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='12',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Local Marketing Agreements</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of our stations have entered into what have
commonly been referred to as local marketing agreements or LMAs.&#160; One typical type of LMA is a programming
agreement between two separately owned television stations serving the same
market, whereby the licensee of one station programs substantial portions of
the broadcast day and sells advertising time during such programming segments
on the other licensee&#146;s station subject to the ultimate editorial and other
controls being exercised by the latter licensee.&#160; We believe these arrangements allow us to
reduce our operating expenses and enhance profitability.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 1999, the FCC established a new local television
ownership rule&nbsp;and decided to attribute LMAs for ownership purposes.&#160; It grandfathered our LMAs that were entered
into prior to November&nbsp;5, 1996, permitting the applicable stations to
continue operations pursuant to the LMAs until the conclusion of the FCC&#146;s 2004
biennial review.&#160; The FCC stated it would
conduct a case-by-case review of grandfathered LMAs and assess the
appropriateness of extending the grandfathering periods.&#160; Subsequently, the FCC invited comments as to
whether, instead of beginning the review of the grandfathered LMAs in 2004, it
should do so in 2006.&#160; The FCC did not
initiate any review of grandfathered LMAs in 2004 or as part of its 2006
quadrennial review.&#160; We do not know when,
or if, the FCC will conduct any such review of grandfathered LMAs.&#160; With respect to LMAs executed on or after November&nbsp;5,
1996, the FCC required that parties come into compliance with the 1999 local
television ownership rule&nbsp;by August&nbsp;6, 2001.&#160; We challenged the 1999 local television
ownership rule&nbsp;in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit, and that
court stayed the enforcement of the divestiture of the post-November&nbsp;5,
1996 LMAs.&#160; In 2002, the D.C. Circuit
ruled in <i>Sinclair Broadcast Group,&nbsp;Inc. v. F.C.C</i>.,
284 F.3d 114 (D.C. Cir. 2002) that the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;was
arbitrary and capricious and remanded the rule&nbsp;to the Commission.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2003, the FCC revised its ownership rules,
including the local television ownership rule. The effective date of the 2003
ownership rules&nbsp;was stayed by the U. S. Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit and the rules&nbsp;were remanded to the FCC.&#160; Because the effective date of the 2003
ownership rules&nbsp;had been stayed and, in connection with the adoption of
those rules, the FCC concluded the 1999 rules&nbsp;could not be justified as
necessary in the public interest, we took the position that an issue exists
regarding whether the FCC has any current legal right to enforce any rules&nbsp;prohibiting
the acquisition of television stations.&#160;
Several parties, including us, filed petitions with the Supreme Court of
the United States seeking review of the Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme
Court denied the petitions in June&nbsp;2005.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In July&nbsp;2006, as part of the FCC&#146;s statutorily
required quadrennial review of its media ownership rules, the FCC released a
Further Notice of Proposed Rule&nbsp;Making seeking comment on how to address
the issues raised by the Third Circuit&#146;s decision, among other things,
remanding the local television ownership rule.&#160;
In January&nbsp;2008, the FCC released an order containing its current
ownership rules, which re-adopted its 1999 local television ownership
rule.&#160; On February&nbsp;8, 2008, we filed
a petition with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit requesting that
the Court direct the FCC to cease its use of the 1999 local television
ownership rule&nbsp;that it re-adopted as the permanent rule&nbsp;in 2008.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On November&nbsp;15, 1999, we entered into a plan and
agreement of merger to acquire through merger WMYA-TV (formerly WBSC-TV) in
Anderson, South Carolina from Cunningham Broadcasting Corporation (Cunningham),
but that transaction was denied by the FCC.&#160;
In light of the change in the 2003 ownership rules, we filed a petition
for reconsideration with the FCC and amended our application to acquire the
license of WMYA-TV.&#160; We also filed
applications in November&nbsp;2003 to acquire the license assets of the
remaining five Cunningham stations: WRGT-TV, Dayton, Ohio; WTAT-TV, Charleston,
South Carolina; WVAH-TV, Charleston, West Virginia; WNUV-TV, Baltimore,
Maryland; and WTTE-TV, Columbus, Ohio.&#160;
Rainbow/PUSH filed a petition to deny these five applications and to
revoke all of our licenses.&#160; The FCC
dismissed our applications in light of the stay of the 2003 ownership rules&nbsp;and
also denied the Rainbow/PUSH petition.&#160;
Rainbow/PUSH filed a petition for reconsideration of that denial and we
filed an application for review of the dismissal.&#160; In 2005, we filed a petition with the U. S.
Court of Appeals for the D. C. Circuit requesting that the Court direct the FCC
to take final action on our applications, but that petition was dismissed.&#160; On January&nbsp;6, 2006, we submitted a
motion to the FCC requesting that it take final action on our
applications.&#160; On February&nbsp;8, 2008,
we filed a petition with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit
requesting that the Court direct the FCC to act on our assignment applications
and to cease its use of the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;that it
re-adopted as the permanent rule&nbsp;in 2008.&#160;
The applications and the associated petition to deny are still
pending.&#160; We believe the Rainbow/PUSH
petition is without merit.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;font-weight:normal;">13</font></i></b></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left">

</font></i></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='13',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Satellite Home Viewer Act (SHVA), The Satellite Home Viewer Improvement Act
(SHVIA) and the Satellite Home Viewer Extension and Reauthorization Act
(SHVERA)</font></i></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In
1988, Congress enacted the Satellite Home Viewer Act (SHVA), which enabled
satellite carriers to provide broadcast programming to those satellite
subscribers who were unable to obtain broadcast network programming
over-the-air.&#160; SHVA did not permit
satellite carriers to retransmit local broadcast television signals directly to
their subscribers.&#160; The Satellite Home
Viewer Improvement Act of 1999 (SHVIA) revised SHVA to reflect changes in the
satellite and broadcasting industry.&#160;
This legislation allowed satellite carriers, until December&nbsp;31,
2004, to provide local television signals by satellite within a station market,
and effective January&nbsp;1, 2002, required satellite carriers to carry all
local signals in any market where they carry any local signals.&#160; On or before July&nbsp;1, 2001, SHVIA
required all television stations to elect to exercise certain &#147;must carry&#148; or &#147;retransmission
consent&#148; rights in connection with their carriage by satellite carriers.&#160; We have entered into compensation agreements
granting the two primary satellite carriers retransmission consent to carry all
our stations.&#160; In December&nbsp;2004,
President Bush signed into law the Satellite Home Viewer Extension and
Reauthorization Act (SHVERA).&#160; SHVERA
extended, until December&nbsp;31, 2009, the rights of broadcasters and
satellite carriers under SHVIA to retransmit local television signals by
satellite.&#160; SHVERA also authorized
satellite delivery of distant network signals, significantly viewed signals and
local low-power television station signals into local markets under defined
circumstances.&#160; With respect to digital
signals, SHVERA established a process to allow satellite carriers to retransmit
distant network signals and significantly viewed signals <font style="background:white;">to subscribers under certain circumstances</font>.&#160; In November&nbsp;2005, the FCC completed a
rulemaking proceeding enabling the satellite carriage of &#147;significantly viewed&#148;
signals.&#160; In December&nbsp;2005, the FCC
concluded a study, as required by SHVERA, regarding the applicable technical
standards for determining when a subscriber may receive a distant digital
network signal.&#160; The carriage of
programming from two network stations to a local market on the same satellite
system could result in a decline in viewership of the local network station,
adversely impacting the revenues of our affected owned and programmed stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Must Carry/Retransmission
Consent</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pursuant
to the Cable Act of 1992, television broadcasters are required to make
triennial elections to exercise either certain &#147;must-carry&#148; or &#147;retransmission
consent&#148; rights in connection with their carriage by cable systems in each
broadcaster&#146;s local market.&#160; Our next
election date is October&nbsp;1, 2008, and the election will cover the period January&nbsp;1,
2009 through December&nbsp;31, 2011.&#160; By
electing the must-carry rights, a broadcaster demands carriage on a specific
channel on cable systems within its DMA, in general, as defined by the Nielsen
DMA Market and Demographic Rank Report of the prior year.&#160; These must-carry rights are not absolute and
their exercise is dependent on variables such as:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the number of activated channels on a cable system;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the location and size of a cable system; and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the amount of programming on a broadcast station that duplicates the
programming of another broadcast station carried by the cable system.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Therefore,
under certain circumstances, a cable system may decline to carry a given
station.&#160; Alternatively, if a broadcaster
chooses to exercise retransmission consent rights, it can prohibit cable
systems from carrying its signal or grant the appropriate cable system the
authority to retransmit the broadcast signal for a fee or other
consideration.&#160; In October&nbsp;2005, we
elected retransmission consent with respect to all of our stations.&#160; Some of these retransmission consent
agreements had been negotiated for cable carriage of our analog and/or digital
signal and are short-term and subject to month-to-month extensions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In February&nbsp;2005,
the FCC adopted an order stating that cable television systems are not required
to carry both a station&#146;s analog and digital signals during the digital
transition period.&#160; Thus, only television
stations operating solely with digital signals are entitled to mandatory carriage
of their digital signal by cable companies.&#160;
In addition, it is technically possible for a television station to
broadcast more than one channel of programming using its digital signal.&#160; The same FCC order clarified that cable
systems need only carry a broadcast station&#146;s primary video stream and not any
of the station&#146;s other programming streams in those situations where a station
chooses to transmit multiple programming streams.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Many
of the viewers of our television stations receive the signal of the stations
via MVPDs.&#160; MVPDs generally transmit our
signals pursuant to permission granted by us in retransmission consent
agreements.&#160; A portion of these
retransmission consent agreements will expire in 2008.&#160; Most agreements expire in 2009.&#160; There can be no assurance that future
negotiations of these agreements will be advantageous to us or that we or the
MVPDs might not determine to terminate some or all of these agreements.&#160; A termination of our retransmission consent
agreements would make it more difficult for our viewers to watch our
programming and could result in lower ratings and a negative financial impact
on us.&#160; There can be no assurances that
we will be able to negotiate mutually acceptable retransmission consent
agreements in the future relating to the carriage of our digital signals.&#160; However, we believe that as these agreements
expire we will be able to negotiate terms as favorable as or more favorable
than the existing agreements.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">14</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='14',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Syndicated
Exclusivity/Territorial Exclusivity</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
FCC&#146;s syndicated exclusivity rules&nbsp;allow local broadcast television
stations to demand that cable operators black out syndicated non-network
programming carried on &#147;distant signals&#148; (i.e. signals of broadcast stations,
including so-called &#147;superstations&#148;, which serve areas substantially removed
from the cable systems&#146; local community).&#160;
The FCC&#146;s network non-duplication rules&nbsp;allow local broadcast,
network affiliated stations to require that cable operators black out duplicate
network programming carried on distant signals.&#160;
However, in a number of markets in which we own or program stations
affiliated with a network, a station that is affiliated with the same network
in a nearby market is carried on cable systems in our markets.&#160; This is not necessarily a violation of the
FCC&#146;s network non-duplication rules.&#160;
However, the carriage of two network stations on the same cable system
could result in a decline of viewership, adversely affecting the revenues of
our owned or programmed stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Digital Television</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
FCC has taken a number of steps to implement digital television (DTV)
broadcasting services.&#160; The FCC has
adopted an allotment table that provides all authorized television stations
with a second channel on which to broadcast a DTV signal. The FCC has attempted
to provide DTV coverage areas that are comparable to stations&#146; existing service
areas.&#160; The FCC has ruled that television
broadcast licensees may use their digital channels for a wide variety of services
such as high-definition television, multiple standard definition television
programming, audio, data and other types of communications, subject to the
requirement that each broadcaster provide at least one free video channel equal
in quality to the current technical standard and further subject to the
requirement that broadcasters pay a fee of 5% of gross revenues from any DTV
ancillary or supplementary service for which there is a subscription fee or for
which the licensee receives a fee from a third party.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">DTV
channels are generally located in the range of channels from channel 2 through
channel 51.&#160; All commercial stations were
required to begin digital broadcasting on May&nbsp;1, 2002.&#160; Under the FCC&#146;s rules, all DTV stations are
required to operate at all times in which their analog stations are
operating.&#160; In September&nbsp;2004, the
FCC eliminated its requirement that a digital station simulcast a certain
percentage of the programming transmitted on its associated analog station.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of December&nbsp;31,
2004, DTV stations were required to meet a certain signal strength standard for
the digital signal coverage in their communities of license.&#160; By July&nbsp;2005, a DTV licensee affiliated
with a top four network (i.e, FOX, ABC, CBS or NBC) that is located in one of
the top 100 markets was required to meet a higher replication standard or lose
interference protection for those areas not covered by the digital signal.&#160; For a station subject to this deadline which
had not yet received a construction permit, the FCC required that such station
build a &#147;checklist&#148; facility by August&nbsp;2005.&#160; For all other commercial DTV licensees, as
well as non-commercial DTV licensees, that have received construction permits,
the deadline for meeting a higher replication standard was July&nbsp;2006.&#160; All of our stations filed a DTV status report
with the FCC, as required, by the February&nbsp;19, 2008 deadline.&#160;&#160; In August&nbsp;2007 we filed a request for
WSMH-DT for an extension and/or waiver of the FCC&#146;s rule&nbsp;permitting
satellite subscribers to qualify, under a digital signal strength test, for
satellite retransmission of distant digital network signals.&#160; The FCC granted the request in October&nbsp;2007.&#160; We will need to seek further extension and
waiver of the extended deadline for WSMH-DT by March&nbsp;18, 2008, and there
is no guarantee that such extension request will be granted.&#160; If the request is not granted, the station
could lose viewers which could adversely impact revenues for that station.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We
operate our television stations at different power levels pursuant to our FCC
licenses, applicable permits or special temporary authority granted by the
FCC.&#160; The following table is a summary of
our operating status as of January&nbsp;31, 2008:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<div align="center">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="92%" style="border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:42.7pt;width:92.12%;">

  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">DTV Operating Status</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="10%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:10.84%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

 <tr>
  <td width="67%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:67.36%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="10%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:10.84%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
