  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">58</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In April&nbsp;2003,
the FCC adopted a policy of graduated sanctions to be imposed upon licensees
who do not meet the FCC&#146;s DTV build-out schedule.&#160; Under the policy, the stations could face
monetary fines and possible loss of any digital construction permits for
non-compliance with the build-out schedule.&#160;
After completion of the transition period, the FCC will reclaim the
non-digital channels.&#160; Congress passed
legislation establishing a hard deadline of February&nbsp;17, 2009 by which
broadcasters must cease using their analog channel.&#160; There can be no assurance that the stations
we own or program will be fully transitioned to digital broadcasts by this
deadline.&#160; A station&#146;s failure to meet
the deadline could result in a loss of interference protection or the
applicable FCC license, adversely impacting the revenues of stations we own or
to which we provide services.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">15</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On December&nbsp;31,
2007, the FCC released an order discussing the progress of the transition to
digital television and imposing new reporting obligations and pre-transition
construction deadlines on digital television station licensees and
permittees.&#160; As of February&nbsp;22, 2008
all but 10 of the television stations we own or to which we provide services
are operating on their authorized post-transition digital channels and have
certified to the FCC that they are doing so in compliance with the new interim
construction deadlines.&#160; As a result of
the order, the remaining 10 television stations, which are not operating on
their post-transition DTV channels, are required to comply with the new
pre-transition construction deadlines, and file construction permit
applications, construction permit extension applications, or tolling requests,
as appropriate.&#160;&#160; There can be no
assurance that the FCC will grant applications filed for these stations or that
the stations will meet the FCC pre-transition deadlines or be fully
transitioned to digital broadcasts by February&nbsp;17, 2009.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On August&nbsp;7,
2007, the FCC released an order which adopted the <strong><b><font face="Times New Roman" style="font-weight:normal;">final DTV table of allotments</font></b></strong>
establishing the post-transition digital channels for all full-power television
stations in the country.&nbsp; On October&nbsp;26, 2007, we filed petitions for
reconsideration of the FCC&#146;s final DTV table for stations WTVZ-DT, WMMP-DT, and
WVTV-DT requesting that the Commission correct the FCC antenna identification
numbers and power levels for the stations set forth in the DTV table.&#160; There is no guarantee that the FCC will make
the requested corrections and a failure of the FCC to do so might result in
decreased service to viewers of those stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Implementation
of digital television has imposed substantial additional costs on television
stations because of the need to replace equipment and because some stations
will need to operate at higher utility costs.&#160;
There can be no assurance that our television stations will be able to
increase revenue to offset such costs.&#160;
In addition, the FCC has proposed imposing new public interest
requirements on television licensees in exchange for their receipt of DTV
channels.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We
believe that the following developments regarding the FCC&#146;s digital regulations
may have effects on us:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Reclamation of analog channels</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
Analog broadcasters are required to cease operation on their assigned
analog spectrum by February&nbsp;17, 2009.&#160;
At that time, the FCC will reclaim this spectrum from broadcasters and
make it available to the entities that have been assigned the spectrum through
FCC auctions.&#160; The FCC envisions that the
reclaimed band will be used for a variety of broadcast-type applications including
two-way interactive services and services using Coded Orthogonal Frequency
Division Multiplexing technology.&#160; We
cannot predict how the development of this spectrum will affect our television
operations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Digital must-carry</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; In February&nbsp;2005,
the FCC adopted an order stating that cable television systems are not required
to carry both a must-carry station&#146;s analog and digital signals during the
digital transition.&#160; The same order also
clarified that a cable system must only carry a must-carry station&#146;s primary
video stream but is not required to carry any of the station&#146;s other
programming streams in those situations where a station chooses to transmit
multiple programming streams.&#160; On September&nbsp;11,
2007, the FCC adopted an order requiring, after the digital transition, all
cable operators to make the primary digital stream of must-carry television
stations viewable by all cable subscribers, regardless of whether they are
using analog or digital television equipment.&#160;
The FCC indicated that it would consider requests for a waiver of this requirement
by small cable system operators, where compliance with that requirement would
be unduly burdensome.&#160; Grant of any such
waiver to a small cable system operator in a market in which we operate could
result in a loss of viewers for our station(s)&nbsp;in that market, which could
negatively impact station revenues.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Multi-Channel Digital Broadcasting</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
FCC rules&nbsp;allow broadcasters to transmit additional digital signals
within the spectrum allocated to each FCC license holder.&#160; We are currently broadcasting a single
digital signal for all but four of our television stations.&#160; During 2006, we began broadcasting a second
digital signal in Baltimore, Maryland.&#160;
In 2006, we also entered into agreements with MyNetworkTV to air
prime-time programming on the second digital signal in Columbus, Ohio, Dayton,
Ohio and Richmond, Virginia.&#160; During
non-prime-time hours these stations air religious, paid-programming, &#147;classic&#148;
syndicated programming and simulcasting of our primary digital channel.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Capital and operating costs</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; We have
incurred and will continue to incur costs to replace equipment in our stations
in order to provide digital television.&#160;
Some of our stations will also incur increased utilities costs as a
result of broadcasting both analog and digital signals during the transition
period.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Children&#146;s
programming</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; In 2004, the FCC established children&#146;s
educational and informational programming obligations for digital multicast
broadcasters and placed restrictions on the increasing commercialization of
children&#146;s programming on both analog and digital broadcast and cable
television systems.&#160; In addition to
imposing its limit as to the amount of commercial matter in children&#146;s
programming (10.5 minutes per hour on weekends and 12 minutes per hour on
weekdays) on all digital or video programming, free or pay, directed to
children 12 years old and younger, the FCC also mandated that digital
broadcasters air an additional half hour of &#147;core&#148; children&#146;s programming for
every 28-hour block of free video programming provided in addition to the main
DTV program stream.&#160; The additional core
children&#146;s programming requirement for digital broadcasters took effect on January&nbsp;2,
2007.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='16',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Emergency
Alert System</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; In November&nbsp;2005, the FCC adopted an
order requiring that digital broadcasters comply with the FCC&#146;s present
Emergency Alert System (EAS) rules.&#160; It
also issued a further notice of proposed rulemaking seeking comments on what
actions the FCC should take to expedite the development of a digitally based
public alert and warning system.&#160; On July&nbsp;12,
2007, the Commission adopted an order allowing mandatory use of EAS by state
governments and requiring that all EAS participants, including television
broadcasters, be able to receive messages formatted pursuant to a procedure to
be adopted by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.&#160; In a further notice, the FCC invited comments
on, among other things, how the EAS rules&nbsp;could be modified to ensure that
non-English speakers and persons with disabilities are reached by EAS messages
and whether local, county, tribal, or other state governmental entities should
be allowed to initiate mandatory state and local alerts.&#160; Any additional EAS requirements on digital
broadcasters could increase our costs.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Restrictions on Broadcast
Programming</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Advertising
of cigarettes and certain other tobacco products on broadcast stations has been
banned for many years.&#160; Various states
also restrict the advertising of alcoholic beverages and, from time to time,
certain members of Congress have contemplated legislation to place restrictions
on the advertisement of such alcoholic beverages.&#160; FCC rules&nbsp;also restrict the amount and
type of advertising which can appear in a program broadcast primarily for an
audience of children 12 years old and younger.&#160;
In addition, the Federal Trade Commission issued guidelines in December&nbsp;2003
and continues to provide advice to help media outlets voluntarily screen out
weight loss product advertisements that are misleading.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Communications Act and FCC rules&nbsp;also place restrictions on the
broadcasting of advertisements by legally qualified candidates for elective
office.&#160; Those restrictions state that:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">stations must provide &#147;reasonable access&#148; for the purchase of time by
legally qualified candidates for federal office;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">stations must provide &#147;equal opportunities&#148; for the purchase of
equivalent amounts of comparable broadcast time by opposing candidates for the
same elective office; and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">during the 45 days preceding a primary or primary run-off election and
during the 60 days preceding a general or special election, legally qualified
candidates for elective office may be charged no more than the station&#146;s &#147;lowest
unit charge&#148; for the same class and amount of time for the same period.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">It is
a violation of federal law and FCC regulations to broadcast obscene or indecent
programming.&#160; FCC licensees are, in
general, responsible for the content of their broadcast programming, including
that supplied by television networks.&#160;
Accordingly, there is a risk of being fined as a result of our broadcast
programming, including network programming.&#160;
As a result of legislation passed in June&nbsp;2006, the maximum forfeiture
amount for the broadcast of indecent or obscene material was increased to
$325,000 from $32,500 for each violation.&#160;
In July&nbsp;2007, a bill was introduced in Congress that would require
the FCC, in enforcing its regulations concerning the broadcast of indecent
programming, to maintain a policy that a single word or image may be considered
indecent.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Programming and Operation</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">General</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The
Communications Act requires broadcasters to serve the &#147;public interest.&#148;&#160; The FCC has relaxed or eliminated many of the
more formalized procedures it had developed in the past to promote the
broadcast of certain types of programming responsive to the needs of a station&#146;s
community of license.&#160; FCC licensees
continue to be required, however, to present programming that is responsive to
the needs and interests of their communities and to maintain certain records
demonstrating such responsiveness.&#160;
Complaints from viewers concerning a station&#146;s programming may be
considered by the FCC when it evaluates renewal applications of a licensee,
although such complaints may be filed at any time and generally may be
considered by the FCC at any time.&#160;
Stations also must pay regulatory and application fees and follow
various rules&nbsp;promulgated under the Communications Act that regulate,
among other things, political advertising, sponsorship identifications, obscene
and indecent broadcasts and technical operations, including limits on radio
frequency radiation.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In
2000, the FCC initiated a rulemaking proceeding to determine whether its requirements
pertaining to television stations&#146; public inspection files were sufficient to
ensure that the public had adequate access to information on how stations were
serving their communities.&#160; In January&nbsp;2008,
the FCC released an order adopting a standardized form for the quarterly
reporting of programming aired in response to issues facing a station&#146;s
community and imposed a requirement that portions of each station&#146;s public
inspection file be placed on the Internet.&#160;
We cannot predict how these requirements will impact our business.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Equal Employment Opportunity</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; On November&nbsp;20,
2002, the FCC adopted rules, effective March&nbsp;10, 2003, requiring licensees
to create equal employment opportunity outreach programs and maintain records
and make filings with the FCC evidencing such </font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">17</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">efforts.&#160; The FCC simultaneously released a notice of
proposed rulemaking seeking comments on whether and how to apply these rules&nbsp;and
policies to part-time positions, defined as less than 30 hours per week.&#160; That rulemaking is still pending.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Children&#146;s Television Programming</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
Television stations are required to broadcast a minimum of three hours
per week of &#147;core&#148; children&#146;s educational programming, which the FCC defines as
programming that:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">has the significant purpose of serving the educational and
informational needs of children 16 years of age and under;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">is regularly scheduled weekly and at least 30 minutes in duration; and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">is aired between the hours of 7:00&nbsp;a.m. and 10:00&nbsp;p.m. local
time.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In
addition, the FCC concluded that starting on January&nbsp;2, 2007, a digital
broadcaster must air an additional half hour of &#147;core&#148; children&#146;s programming
per every increment of 1 to 28 hours of free video programming provided in
addition to the main DTV program stream.&#160;
Furthermore, &#147;core&#148; children&#146;s educational programs, in order to qualify
as such, are required to be identified as educational and informational
programs over-the-air at the time they are broadcast and are required to be
identified in the children&#146;s programming reports, which are required to be
placed quarterly in stations&#146; public inspection files and filed quarterly with
the FCC.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On April&nbsp;17,
2007, the FCC requested comments on the status of children&#146;s television
programming and compliance with the Children&#146;s Television Act and the FCC&#146;s
rules.&#160; That proceeding is still pending.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Violent
Programming</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; In 2004, the FCC initiated a notice of
inquiry seeking comments on issues relating to the presentation of violent
programming on television and its impact on children.&#160; On April&nbsp;25, 2007, the FCC released a
report concluding that there is strong evidence that exposure to violence in
the media can increase aggressive behavior in children, at least in the short
term.&#160; Accordingly, the FCC concluded
that it would be in the public interest to regulate such programming and
Congress could do so consistent with the First Amendment.&#160; As possible solutions, the FCC suggested,
among other things, a voluntary industry initiative to reduce the amount of
excessively violent programming viewed by children and also proposed several
viewer-initiated blocking proposals, such as the provision of video channels by
multi-channel video programming distributors on family tiers or on an a la
carte basis.&#160; We cannot predict what rules&nbsp;the
FCC will adopt or how they will affect our business.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Television Program Content</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The
television industry has developed an FCC approved ratings system that is
designed to provide parents with information regarding the content of the
programming being aired.&#160; Furthermore,
the FCC requires certain television sets to include the so-called &#147;V-chip&#148;, a
computer chip that allows the blocking of rated programming.&#160; It is a violation of federal law and FCC
regulations to broadcast obscene or indecent programming.&#160; FCC licensees are, in general, responsible
for the content of their broadcast programming, including that supplied by
television networks.&#160; Accordingly, there
is a risk of being fined as a result of our broadcast programming, including
network programming.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Localism.&#160; </font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2004, the FCC initiated a notice of inquiry seeking
comments on what actions, if any, it should take to ensure that licensees air
programming that is responsive to the interests and needs of their
communities.&#160; In January&nbsp;2008, the
FCC released a notice of proposed rulemaking proposing, among other things, to
require licensees to establish permanent advisory boards and to modify the FCC&#146;s
renewal application processing guidelines to ensure that all broadcasters provide
some locally oriented programming.&#160;
Additionally, the FCC proposed to grant Class&nbsp;A status to
additional low-power television stations, providing such stations additional
interference protection from full-power television stations and requiring such stations
to provide local programming.&#160; We cannot
predict what rules&nbsp;the FCC will adopt and how it will affect our business.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;<i>Closed Captioning</i>.&#160; Effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, all new
nonexempt analog and digital English language programming was required to be
captioned.&#160; Additionally, the FCC, in July&nbsp;2005,
initiated a rulemaking to determine whether any revisions should be made to
enhance the effectiveness of its closed captioning rules, including monitoring
compliance and the establishment of a base forfeiture amount for noncompliance.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pending Matters</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Congress
and the FCC have under consideration and in the future may consider and adopt,
new laws, regulations and policies regarding a wide variety of matters that
could affect, directly or indirectly, the operation, ownership and
profitability of our broadcast stations, result in the loss of audience share
and advertising revenues for our broadcast stations and affect our ability to
acquire additional broadcast stations or finance such acquisitions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Other
matters that could affect our broadcast properties include technological
innovations and developments generally affecting competition in the mass
communications industry, such as direct television broadcast satellite service,
Class&nbsp;A television service, the continued establishment of wireless cable
systems and low power television stations, digital television technologies, the
internet and mobility and portability of our broadcast signal to hand-held
devices.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For
example, in October&nbsp;2006, the FCC adopted an order taking the initial
steps toward allowing new low power devices to operate in the broadcast
television spectrum at locations where channels in that spectrum are not in
use.&#160; Initial FCC tests of prototype
devices failed to show that the tested devices could predictably sense the
presence of television broadcast signals and thus could result in interference
to broadcast stations.&#160; In October&nbsp;2007,
the FCC announced that it would be conducting further laboratory and field
testing of prototype devices.&#160; The
operation of such devices could cause harmful interference to our broadcast
signals adversely affecting the operation and profitability of our stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December&nbsp;2006,
the FCC adopted an order prohibiting franchising authorities from unreasonably
refusing to award competitive franchises for the provision of cable
services.&#160; The order could facilitate the
provision of such services by telephone companies, increasing competition to
our stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Other Considerations</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
preceding summary is not a complete discussion of all provisions of the
Communications Act, the 1996 Act or other congressional acts or of the
regulations and policies of the FCC.&#160; For
further information, reference should be made to the Communications Act, the
1996 Act, other congressional acts and regulations and public notices
circulated from time to time by the FCC.&#160;
There are additional regulations and policies of the FCC and other
federal agencies that govern political broadcasts, advertising, equal
employment opportunity and other matters affecting our business and operations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATION</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Prior
to our ownership or operation of our facilities, substances or waste that are,
or might be considered, hazardous under applicable environmental laws may have
been generated, used, stored or disposed of at certain of those
facilities.&#160; In addition, environmental
conditions relating to the soil and groundwater at or under our facilities may
be affected by the proximity of nearby properties that have generated, used,
stored or disposed of hazardous substances.&#160;
As a result, it is possible that we could become subject to
environmental liabilities in the future in connection with these facilities
under applicable environmental laws and regulations.&#160; Although we believe that we are in
substantial compliance with such environmental requirements and have not in the
past been required to incur significant costs in connection therewith, there can
be no assurance that our costs to comply with such requirements will not
increase in the future.&#160; We presently
believe that none of our properties have any condition that is likely to have a
material adverse effect on our consolidated balance sheets, consolidated
statements of operations or consolidated statements of cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">COMPETITION</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our
television stations compete for audience share and advertising revenue with
other television stations in their respective designated market areas (DMAs),
as well as with other advertising media such as radio, newspapers, magazines,
outdoor advertising, transit advertising, telecommunications providers,
internet, yellow page&nbsp;directories, direct mail, MVPDs and wireless
video.&#160; Some competitors are part of
larger organizations with substantially greater financial, technical and other
resources than we have.&#160; Other factors
that are material to a television station&#146;s competitive position include signal
coverage, local program acceptance, network affiliation, audience
characteristics and assigned broadcast frequency.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Television Competition</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; Competition
in the television broadcasting industry occurs primarily in individual
DMAs.&#160; Generally, a television
broadcasting station in one DMA does not compete with stations in other
DMAs.&#160; Our television stations are located
in highly competitive DMAs.&#160; In addition,
certain of our DMAs are overlapped by over-the-air and MVPDs of stations in
adjacent DMAs, which tends to spread viewership and advertising expenditures
over a larger number of television stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Broadcast
television stations compete for advertising revenues primarily with other
broadcast television stations, radio stations, cable channels, MVPDs serving
the same market, as well as with newspapers, the internet, yellow page&nbsp;directories,
direct mail, outdoor advertising operators and transit advertisers.&#160; Television stations compete for audience
share primarily on the basis of program popularity, which has a direct effect
on advertising rates.&#160; Our network
affiliated stations are largely dependent upon the performance of network
provided programs in order to attract viewers.&#160;
Non-network time periods are programmed by the station primarily with
syndicated programs purchased for cash, cash and barter or barter-only, as well
as through self-produced news, public affairs programs, live local sporting
events, paid-programming and other entertainment programming.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">19</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bi.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:06 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Television
advertising rates are based upon factors which include the size of the DMA in
which the station operates, a program&#146;s popularity among the viewers that an
advertiser wishes to attract, the number of advertisers competing for the
available time, the demographic makeup of the DMA served by the station, the
availability of alternative advertising media in the DMA including radio,
MVPDs, internet, newspapers and yellow page&nbsp;directories, direct mail, the
aggressiveness and knowledge of the sales forces in the DMA and development of
projects, features and programs that tie advertiser messages to programming.&#160; We believe that our sales and programming
strategies allow us to compete effectively for advertising revenues within our
DMAs.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
broadcasting industry is continuously faced with technical changes and
innovations, competing entertainment and communications media, changes in labor
conditions and governmental restrictions or actions of federal regulatory
bodies, including the FCC, any of which could possibly have a material affect
on a television station&#146;s operations and profits.&#160; For instance, the FCC has established Class&nbsp;A
television service for qualifying low power television stations.&#160; This Class&nbsp;A designation provides low
power television stations, which ordinarily have no broadcast frequency rights
when the low power signal conflicts with a signal from any full power stations,
some additional frequency rights.&#160; These
rights may allow low power stations to compete more effectively with full power
stations.&#160; We cannot predict the effect
of increased competition from Class&nbsp;A television stations in markets where
we have full power television stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There
are sources of video service other than conventional television stations, the
most common being cable television, which can increase competition for a
broadcast television station by bringing into its market additional program
channels.&#160; These narrow program channels
serve as low rated, expensive programs to local advertisers.&#160; Other principal sources of competition
include home video exhibition and Direct Broadcast Satellite (DBS) services and
Broadband Radio Service (BRS).&#160; DBS and
cable operators, in particular, compete aggressively for advertising revenues.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Moreover,
technology advances and regulatory changes affecting programming delivery
though fiber optic telephone lines and video compression could lower entry
barriers for new video channels and encourage the further development of
increasingly specialized &#147;niche&#148; programming.&#160;
Telephone companies are permitted to provide video distribution services
via radio communication, on a common carrier basis, as &#147;cable systems&#148; or as &#147;open
video systems&#148;, each pursuant to different regulatory schemes.&#160; Additionally, in January&nbsp;2004, the FCC
concluded an auction for licenses operating in the 12 GHz band that can be used
to provide multi-channel video programming distribution.&#160; Those licenses were granted in July&nbsp;2004.&#160; We are unable to predict what other video
technologies might be considered in the future or the effect that technological
and regulatory changes will have on the broadcast television industry and on
the future profitability and value of a particular broadcast television
station.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">DTV
broadcasts are currently available in virtually all viewing markets.&#160; The transition of our viewers from the
current analog broadcast format to a digital format is scheduled to occur on February&nbsp;17,
2009.&#160; We are currently exploring whether
or not television broadcasting will be enhanced significantly by the
development and increased availability of DTV technology.&#160; This technology has the potential to permit
us to provide viewers multiple channels of digital television over each of our
existing standard digital channels, to provide certain programming in high
definition television format and to deliver other channels of information in
the forms of data and programming to the internet, to PCs and mobile
devices.&#160; These additional capabilities
may provide us with additional sources of revenue, as well as additional
competition.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We
also compete for programming, which involves negotiating with national program
distributors or syndicators that sell first-run and rerun packages of
programming.&#160; Our stations compete for
exclusive access to those programs against in-market broadcast station
competitors for syndicated products and with national cable networks.&#160; Public broadcasting stations generally
compete with commercial broadcasters for viewers, but not for advertising
dollars.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We
believe we compete favorably against other television stations because of our
management skill and experience, our ability historically to generate revenue
share greater than our audience share, our network affiliations and our local
program acceptance.&#160; In addition, we
believe that we benefit from the operation of multiple broadcast properties,
affording us certain non-quantifiable economies of scale and competitive
advantages in the purchase of programming.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">EMPLOYEES</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of February&nbsp;21,
2008, we had approximately 2,760 employees.&#160;
Approximately 100 employees are represented by labor unions under
certain collective bargaining agreements.&#160;
We have not experienced any significant labor problems and consider our
overall labor relations to be good.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

</div>

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AVAILABLE INFORMATION</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our
internet address is: www.sbgi.net. We make available, free of charge through
our website, our annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K, quarterly reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q,
current reports on Form&nbsp;8-K and amendments to those reports filed or
furnished pursuant to Section&nbsp;13(a)&nbsp;or 15(d)&nbsp;of the Exchange Act
of 1934 as soon as reasonably practicable after such documents are
electronically submitted to the SEC.&#160; In
addition, a replay of each of our quarterly earnings conference calls is
available on our website until the subsequent quarter&#146;s earnings call.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 1A.</font></b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">RISK FACTORS<a name="Item1a_RiskFactors_230440"></a></font></h2>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">You should
carefully consider the risks described below before investing in our
securities.&#160; Our business is also subject
to the risks that affect many other companies such as general economic
conditions, geopolitical events, competition, technological obsolescence and
employee relations.&#160; The risks described
below, along with risks not currently known to us or that we currently believe
are immaterial, may impair our business operations and our liquidity in an
adverse way.</font></i></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our advertising revenue
can vary substantially from period to period based on many factors beyond our
control.&#160; This volatility affects our
operating results and may reduce our ability to repay indebtedness or reduce
the market value of our securities.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We
rely on sales of advertising time for most of our revenues and, as a result,
our operating results are sensitive to the amount of advertising revenue we
generate.&#160; If we generate less revenue,
it may be more difficult for us to repay our indebtedness and the value of our
business may decline.&#160; Our ability to
sell advertising time depends on:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the levels of automobile advertising, which generally represents about
one fifth of our advertising revenue;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the health of the economy in the area where our television stations are
located and in the nation as a whole;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the popularity of our programming;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">changes in the makeup of the population in the areas where our stations
are located;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the activities of our competitors, including increased competition from
other forms of advertising-based mediums, such as other broadcast television
stations, radio stations, MVPDs and internet and broadband content providers
serving in the same markets; and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">other factors that may be beyond our control.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our substantial
indebtedness could adversely affect our financial condition and prevent us from
fulfilling our debt obligations.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We
have a high level of debt, totaling $1.3 billion at December&nbsp;31, 2007,
compared to the book value of shareholders&#146; equity of $252.8 million on the
same date.&#160; Our relatively high level of
debt poses the following risks, particularly in periods of declining revenues:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">we use a significant portion of our cash flow to pay principal and
interest on our outstanding debt, limiting the amount available for working
capital, capital expenditures, dividends and other general corporate purposes;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">our lenders may not be as willing to lend additional amounts to us for
future working capital needs, additional acquisitions or other purposes;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">if our cash flow were inadequate to make interest and principal
payments, we might have to refinance our indebtedness or sell one or more of
our stations to reduce debt service obligations;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">21</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Symbol" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">our ability to finance working capital needs and
general corporate purposes for the public and private markets, as well as the
associated cost of funding is dependent, in part, by our credit ratings.&#160; As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, our credit
ratings, as assigned by Moody&#146;s Investor Services (Moody&#146;s) and Standard&nbsp;&amp;
Poor&#146;s Ratings Services (S&amp;P) were:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
