  </td>
  <td width="17%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:17.96%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">S&amp;P</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="48%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:48.8%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Senior Secured
  Credit Facilities</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:12.46%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:16.62%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Baa3</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:4.16%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="17%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:17.96%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BB+</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="48%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:48.8%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Corporate Credit</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:12.46%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:16.62%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Ba3</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:4.16%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="17%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:17.96%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BB-</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="48%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:48.8%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Senior
  Subordinated Notes</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:12.46%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:16.62%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Ba3</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:4.16%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="17%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:17.96%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">B</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="48%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:48.8%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">4.875% and 3.0%
  Convertible Senior Notes</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:12.46%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:16.62%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">B1</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:4.16%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="17%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:17.96%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">B</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
credit ratings previously stated are not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold
securities and may be subject to revision or withdrawal by the assigning rating
organization.&#160; Each rating should be
evaluated independently of any other rating.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">we may be more vulnerable to adverse economic conditions than less
leveraged competitors and thus, less able to withstand competitive pressures;
and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">of the $1.3 billion of total debt outstanding, $0.3 billion relates to
our Bank Credit Agreement.&#160; The interest
rate under our Bank Credit Agreement is a floating rate and will increase if
interest rates increase.&#160; This will
reduce the funds available to repay our obligations and for operations and
future business opportunities and will make us more vulnerable to the
consequences of our leveraged capital structure.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Any of
these events could reduce our ability to generate cash available for investment,
debt repayment, capital improvements or to respond to events that would enhance
profitability.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We may be able to incur significantly
more debt in the future, which will increase each of the foregoing risks
related to our indebtedness.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At December&nbsp;31, 2007, we had $175.0 million
available (subject to certain borrowing conditions) for additional borrowings
under the Bank Credit Agreement, all of which was available under our current
borrowing capacity.&#160; In addition, under
the terms of our debt instruments, we may be able to incur substantial
additional indebtedness in the future, including additional senior debt and in
some cases, secured debt.&#160; Provided we
meet certain financial and other covenants, the terms of the indentures
governing our outstanding notes do not prohibit us from incurring such
additional indebtedness.&#160; If we incur
additional indebtedness, the risks described above relating to having
substantial debt could intensify.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We must purchase
television programming in advance based on expectations about future
revenues.&#160; Actual revenues may be lower
than our expectations.&#160; If this happens,
we could experience losses that may make our securities less valuable.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">One of
our most significant costs is television programming.&#160; Our ability to generate revenue to cover this
cost may affect the value of our securities.&#160;
If a particular program is not popular in relation to its costs, we may
not be able to sell enough advertising time to cover the costs of the program.&#160; Since we generally purchase programming
content from others rather than produce it ourselves, we have limited control
over the costs of the programming.&#160; We
usually must purchase programming several years in advance and may have to
commit to purchase more than one year&#146;s worth of programming.&#160; Finally, we may replace programs that are
doing poorly before we have recaptured any significant portion of the costs we
incurred or before we have fully amortized the costs.&#160; Any of these factors could reduce our
revenues or otherwise cause our costs to escalate relative to revenues.&#160; These factors are exacerbated during a weak
advertising market.&#160; Additionally, our
business is subject to the popularity of the programs provided by the networks
with which we have network affiliation agreements or which provide us
programming.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Commitments we have made
to our lenders limit our ability to take actions that could increase the value
of our securities or may require us to take actions that decrease the value of
our securities.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our existing financing
agreements prevent us from taking certain actions and require us to meet
certain tests.&#160; These restrictions and
tests may require us to conduct our business in ways that make it more
difficult for us to repay our indebtedness or decrease the value of our business.&#160; These restrictions and tests include the
following:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">restrictions on additional debt;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">restrictions on our ability to pledge our
assets as security for our indebtedness;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">22</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='22',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bk.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:07 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.5in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">restrictions on payment of dividends, the
repurchase of stock and other payments relating to capital stock;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.5in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">restrictions on some sales of assets and
the use of proceeds from asset sales;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.5in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">restrictions on mergers and other
acquisitions, satisfaction of conditions for acquisitions and a limit on the
total amount of acquisitions without the consent of bank lenders;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.5in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">restrictions on the type of business we
and our subsidiaries may operate in; and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.5in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">financial ratio and condition tests
including the ratio of earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and
amortization, as adjusted (adjusted EBITDA) to certain of our fixed expenses,
the ratio of adjusted EBITDA to senior indebtedness and adjusted EBITDA to
operating company indebtedness.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Future financing
arrangements may contain additional restrictions and tests.&#160; All of these restrictive covenants may limit
our ability to pursue our business strategies, prevent us from taking action
that could increase the value of our securities or may require actions that
decrease the value of our securities.&#160; In
addition, we may fail to meet the tests and thereby default on one or more of
our obligations (particularly if the economy were to soften and thereby reduce
our advertising revenues).&#160; If we default
on our obligations, creditors could require immediate payment of the
obligations or foreclose on collateral.&#160;
If this happens, we could be forced to sell assets or take other actions
that could significantly reduce the value of our securities and we may not have
sufficient assets or funds to pay our debt obligations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We may lose a large amount of programming if a network
terminates its affiliation with us, which could increase our costs and/or
reduce revenue.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our 58 television
stations that we own and operate, or to which we provide programming services
or sales services, are affiliated with networks.&#160; The networks produce and distribute
programming in exchange for each station&#146;s commitment to air the programming at
specified times and for commercial announcement time during programming.&#160; The amount and quality of programming
provided by each network varies.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The non-renewal or
termination of any of our network affiliation agreements would prevent us from
being able to carry programming of the relevant network.&#160; This loss of programming would require us to
obtain replacement programming, which may involve higher costs and which may
not be as attractive to our target audiences, resulting in reduced
revenues.&#160; Upon the termination of any of
the above affiliation agreements, we would be required to establish a new
affiliation agreement with another network or operate as an independent
station.&#160; At such time, the remaining
value of the network affiliation asset could become impaired and we would be
required to write down the value of the asset.&#160;
At this time, we cannot predict the final outcome of future negotiations
and what impact, if any, they may have on our consolidated balance sheets,
consolidated statements of operations or consolidated statements of cash
flows.&#160; See <i>Item 1.
Business, Television Broadcasting</i> table for further information
regarding our affiliation agreements.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 31.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">A change
in a critical accounting estimate that affects the accounting treatment of
goodwill and FCC licenses could cause material future losses due to asset
impairment.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June&nbsp;2001, the
Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) approved SFAS No.&nbsp;142, <i>Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets</i> (SFAS 142).&#160; SFAS 142 requires companies to cease
amortizing goodwill and certain other intangible assets including FCC licenses.&#160; SFAS 142 also establishes a method of testing
goodwill and FCC licenses for impairment on an annual basis, or on an interim
basis if an event occurs that would reduce the fair value of a reporting unit
below its carrying value.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We test our goodwill and
FCC licenses for impairment.&#160; To perform
this test, we estimate the fair values of our station assets and liabilities
using a combination of observed prices paid for similar assets and liabilities,
discounted cash flow models and appraisals.&#160;
We make certain critical estimates about the future revenue growth rates
within each of our markets as well as the discount rates that would be used by
market participants in an arms-length transaction.&#160; If these growth rates decline or if the
discount rate increases, our goodwill and/or FCC licenses could be
impaired.&#160; An impairment of some or all
of the value of these assets could result in a material effect on the
consolidated statements of operations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">23</font></b></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='23',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bk.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:07 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Key officers and
directors have financial interests that are different and sometimes opposite
our own and we may engage in transactions with these officers and directors
that may benefit them to the detriment of other securityholders.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Some of our officers,
directors and majority shareholders own stock or partnership interests in
businesses that engage in television broadcasting, do business with us or
otherwise do business that conflicts with our interests.&#160; They may transact some business with us upon
approval by the independent members of our Board of Directors even if there is
a conflict of interest or they may engage in business competitive to our
business and those transactions may benefit the officers, directors or majority
shareholders to the detriment of our securityholders.&#160; David D. Smith, Frederick G. Smith, and J.
Duncan Smith are each an officer and director of Sinclair and Robert E. Smith
is a director of Sinclair.&#160; Together, the
Smiths hold shares of our common stock that control the outcome of most matters
submitted to a vote of shareholders.&#160; The
Smiths own a controlling interest in a television station which we program
pursuant to an LMA.&#160; The Smiths also own
businesses that lease real property and tower space to us and engage in other
transactions with us.&#160; David D. Smith,
Frederick G. Smith, J. Duncan Smith, Robert E. Smith and David B. Amy, our
Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, together own less than
2.8% of Allegiance Capital Limited Partnership, a limited partnership in which
we hold a 96.7% interest.&#160; Also, David D.
Smith, Frederick G. Smith, J. Duncan Smith and Robert E. Smith together own
less than 1.0% of the stock of G1440, a company of which we own approximately
94.0% and David D. Smith owns less than 0.1% of Acrodyne Communications,&nbsp;Inc.,
a company of which we own approximately 82.3%.&#160;
We can give no assurance that these transactions or any transactions
that we may enter into in the future with our officers, directors or majority
shareholders, have been, or will be, negotiated on terms as favorable to us as
we would obtain from unrelated parties.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Maryland
law and our financing agreements limit the extent to which our officers,
directors and majority shareholders may transact business with us and pursue
business opportunities that we might pursue.&#160;
These limitations do not, however, prohibit all such transactions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For
additional information regarding our related person transactions, see <i>Note 12. Related Person Transactions,</i> in
the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Smiths exercise
control over most matters submitted to a shareholder vote and may have
interests that differ from yours.&#160; They
may, therefore, take actions that are not in the interests of other
securityholders.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">David
D. Smith, Frederick G. Smith, J. Duncan Smith and Robert E. Smith hold shares
representing approximately 85% of the common stock voting rights and,
therefore, control the outcome of most matters submitted to a vote of
shareholders, including, but not limited to, electing directors, adopting
amendments to our certificate of incorporation and approving corporate
transactions.&#160; The Smiths hold
substantially all of the Class&nbsp;B Common Stock, which have ten votes per
share.&#160; Our Class&nbsp;A Common Stock has
only one vote per share.&#160; In addition,
the Smiths hold half our board of directors&#146; seats and, therefore, have the
power to exert significant influence over our corporate management and
policies.&#160; The Smiths have entered into a
stockholders&#146; agreement pursuant to which they have agreed to vote for each
other as candidates for election to the board of directors until June&nbsp;13,
2015.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Circumstances
may occur in which the interests of the Smiths, as the controlling security
holders, could be in conflict with the interests of other securityholders and
the Smiths would have the ability to cause us to take actions in their
interest.&#160; In addition, the Smiths could
pursue acquisitions, divestitures or other transactions that, in their
judgment, could enhance their equity investment, even though such transactions
might involve risks to our other securityholders.&#160; (See <i>Item
12. Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management and Related
Stockholder Matters</i> and <i>Item 13.
Certain Relationships and Related Transactions, </i>which will be included as part of our Proxy
Statement for our 2008 Annual Meeting.)</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain features of our
capital structure that discourage others from attempting to acquire our company
may prevent our securityholders from receiving a premium on their securities or
result in a lower price for our securities.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The control the Smiths have over shareholder votes may
discourage other parties from trying to acquire us.&#160; Anyone trying to acquire us would likely
offer to pay more for shares of Class&nbsp;A Common Stock than the amount those
shares were trading for in the open market at the time of the offer.&#160; If the voting rights of the Smiths discourage
such takeover attempts, shareholders may be denied the opportunity to receive
such a premium.&#160; The general level of
prices for Class&nbsp;A Common Stock might also be lower than it would
otherwise be if these deterrents to takeovers did not exist.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Federal regulation of the
broadcasting industry limits our operating flexibility, which may affect our
ability to generate revenue or reduce our costs.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC regulates our business, just as it does all
other companies in the broadcasting industry.&#160;
We must ask the FCC&#146;s approval whenever we need a new license, seek to
renew, assign or modify a license, purchase a new station, sell an </font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">24</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='24',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bk.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:07 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">existing station or transfer the control of one of our
subsidiaries that holds a license.&#160; Our
FCC licenses and those of the stations we program pursuant to LMAs are critical
to our operations; we cannot operate without them.&#160; We cannot be certain that the FCC will renew
these licenses in the future or approve new acquisitions.&#160; If licenses are not renewed or acquisitions
approved, we may lose revenue that we otherwise could have earned.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, Congress and the FCC may, in the future,
adopt new laws, regulations and policies regarding a wide variety of matters
(including technological changes) that could, directly or indirectly,
materially and adversely affect the operation and ownership of our broadcast
properties.&#160; (See <i>Item 1. Business.</i>)</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">The FCC&#146;s multiple ownership rules&nbsp;limit
our ability to operate multiple television stations in some markets and may
result in a reduction in our revenue or prevent us from reducing costs.&#160; Changes in these rules&nbsp;may threaten our
existing strategic approach to certain television markets.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Changes in Rules&nbsp;on Television Ownership</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Congress passed a bill requiring the FCC to establish
a national audience reach cap of 39% and President Bush signed the bill into
law on January&nbsp;23, 2004.&#160; This law
permits broadcast television owners to own more television stations nationally,
potentially affecting our competitive position.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June&nbsp;2003, the FCC adopted new multiple
ownership rules.&#160; In July&nbsp;2004, the
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit issued a decision which upheld a portion
of such rules&nbsp;and remanded the matter to the FCC for further justification
of the rules.&#160; The court also issued a
stay of the 2003 rules&nbsp;pending the remand.&#160;
Several parties, including us, filed petitions with the Supreme Court of
the United States seeking review of the Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme
Court denied the petitions in June&nbsp;2005.&#160;
In July&nbsp;2006, as part of the FCC&#146;s statutorily required quadrennial
review of its media ownership rules, the FCC released a Further Notice of
Proposed Rule&nbsp;Making seeking comment on how to address the issues raised
by the Third Circuit&#146;s decision, among other things, remanding the local
television ownership rule.&#160; In January&nbsp;2008,
the FCC released an order containing its current ownership rules, which
re-adopted its 1999 local television ownership rule.&#160; On February&nbsp;8, 2008, we filed a petition
with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit requesting that the Court
direct the FCC to cease its use of the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;that
it re-adopted as the permanent rule&nbsp;in 2008.&#160; We cannot predict the outcome of that
proceeding, which could significantly impact our business.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Changes in Rules&nbsp;on Local Marketing Agreements</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of our stations have entered into what have
commonly been referred to as local marketing agreements or LMAs.&#160; One typical type of LMA is a programming
agreement between two separately owned television stations serving the same
market, whereby the licensee of one station programs substantial portions of
the broadcast day and sells advertising time during such programming segments
on the other licensee&#146;s station subject to the ultimate editorial and other
controls being exercised by the latter licensee.&#160; We believe these arrangements allow us to
reduce our operating expenses and enhance profitability.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the FCC ownership rules&nbsp;adopted in 2003, we
would be allowed to continue to program most of the stations with which we have
an LMA.&#160; In the absence of a waiver, the
2003 ownership rules&nbsp;would require us to terminate or modify three of our
LMAs in markets where both the station we own and the station with which we
have an LMA are ranked among the top four stations in their particular
designated market area.&#160; The FCC&#146;s 2003 ownership
rules&nbsp;include specific provisions permitting waivers of this &#147;top four
restriction&#148;.&#160; Although there can be no
assurances, we have studied the application of the 2003 ownership rules&nbsp;to
our markets and believe we are qualified for waivers.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">When the FCC decided to attribute LMAs for ownership
purposes in 1999, it grandfathered our LMAs that were entered into prior to November&nbsp;5,
1996, permitting the applicable stations to continue operations pursuant to the
LMAs until the conclusion of the FCC&#146;s 2004 biennial review.&#160; The FCC stated it would conduct a
case-by-case review of grandfathered LMAs and assess the appropriateness of
extending the grandfathering periods.&#160;
Subsequently, the FCC invited comments as to whether, instead of
beginning the review of the grandfathered LMAs in 2004, it should do so in
2006.&#160; The FCC did not initiate any such
review of grandfathered LMAs in 2004 and has not indicated it would do so as
part of its 2006 quadrennial review.&#160; We
do not know when, or if, the FCC will conduct any such review of grandfathered
LMAs.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Because
the effective date of the 2003 ownership rules&nbsp;has been stayed and, in
connection with the adoption of those rules, the FCC concluded the old rules&nbsp;could
not be justified as necessary to the public interest, we have taken the
position that an issue exists regarding whether the FCC has any current legal
right to enforce any rules&nbsp;prohibiting the acquisition of television
stations.&#160; The FCC, however, dismissed
our applications to acquire certain LMA stations.&#160; On November&nbsp;15, 1999, we entered into a
plan and agreement of merger to acquire through merger WMYA-TV (formerly
WBSC-TV) in Anderson, South Carolina from Cunningham Broadcasting Corporation
(Cunningham), but that transaction was denied by the FCC.&#160; In light of the change in the 2003 ownership
rules, we have filed a petition </font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">25</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='25',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bk.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:07 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">for
reconsideration with the FCC and amended our application to acquire the license
of WMYA-TV.&#160; We also filed applications
in November&nbsp;2003 to acquire the license assets of the remaining five
Cunningham stations: WRGT-TV, Dayton, Ohio; WTAT-TV, Charleston, South
Carolina; WVAH-TV, Charleston, West Virginia; WNUV-TV, Baltimore, Maryland; and
WTTE-TV, Columbus, Ohio.&#160; Rainbow/PUSH filed
a petition to deny these five applications and to revoke all of our
licenses.&#160; The FCC dismissed our
applications in light of the stay of the 2003 rules&nbsp;and also denied the
Rainbow/PUSH petition.&#160; Rainbow/PUSH
filed a petition for reconsideration of that denial and we filed an application
for review of the dismissal, which may be impacted by the remand of the FCC&#146;s
2003 ownership rules.&#160; In 2005, we filed
a petition with the U. S. Court of Appeals for the D. C. Circuit requesting
that the Court direct the FCC to take final action on our applications, but
that petition was dismissed.&#160; On January&nbsp;6,
2006, we submitted a motion to the FCC requesting that it take final action on
our applications and that request is pending.&#160;
On February&nbsp;8, 2008, we filed a petition with the U.S. Court of
Appeals for the D.C. Circuit requesting that the Court direct the FCC to act on
our assignment applications and to cease its use of the 1999 local television
ownership rule&nbsp;that it re-adopted as the permanent rule&nbsp;in 2008. &#160;The applications and the associated petition
to deny are still pending.&#160; We believe
the Rainbow/PUSH petition is without merit.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">If we are required to terminate or modify our LMAs,
our business could be affected in the following ways:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Losses on investments</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
As part of our LMA arrangements, we own the non-license assets used by
the stations with which we have LMAs.&#160; If
certain of these LMA arrangements are no longer permitted, we would be forced
to sell these assets, restructure our agreements or find another use for
them.&#160; If this happens, the market for
such assets may not be as good as when we purchased them and, therefore, we
cannot be certain of a favorable return on our original investments.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Termination penalties</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160;
If the FCC requires us to modify or terminate existing LMAs before the
terms of the LMAs expire, or under certain circumstances, we elect not to
extend the terms of the LMAs, we may be forced to pay termination penalties
under the terms of some of our LMAs.&#160; Any
such termination penalties could be material.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Use of outsourcing agreements</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition to our LMAs, we have entered into four
(and may seek opportunities for additional) outsourcing agreements in which our
stations provide or are provided various non-programming related services such
as sales, operational and managerial services to or by other stations.&#160; Pursuant to these agreements, one of our
stations in Nashville, Tennessee and Cedar Rapids, Iowa currently provides
services to another station in the market and another party provides services
to our stations in Peoria/Bloomington, Illinois and Rochester, New York.&#160; We believe this structure allows stations to
achieve operational efficiencies and economies of scale, which should otherwise
improve broadcast cash flow and competitive positions.&#160; While television joint sales agreements
(JSAs) are not currently attributable, on August&nbsp;2, 2004, the FCC released
a notice of proposed rulemaking seeking comments on its tentative conclusion
that television joint sales agreements should be attributable.&#160; We cannot predict the outcome of this
proceeding, nor can we predict how any changes, together with possible changes
to the ownership rules, would apply to our existing outsourcing agreements.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Failure of owner/licensee to exercise control</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC requires the owner/licensee of a station to
maintain independent control over the programming and operations of the
station.&#160; As a result, the
owners/licensees of those stations with which we have LMAs or outsourcing
agreements can exert their control in ways that may be counter to our
interests, including the right to preempt or terminate programming in certain
instances.&#160; The preemption and
termination rights cause some uncertainty as to whether we will be able to air
all of the programming that we have purchased under our LMAs and therefore,
uncertainty about the advertising revenue that we will receive from such
programming.&#160; In addition, if the FCC
determines that the owner/licensee is not exercising sufficient control, it may
penalize the owner licensee by a fine, revocation of the license for the
station or a denial of the renewal of that license.&#160; Any one of these scenarios might result in a
reduction of our cash flow and an increase in our operating costs or margins,
especially the revocation of or denial of renewal of a license.&#160; In addition, penalties might also affect our
qualifications to hold FCC licenses, putting our own licenses at risk.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competition from other
broadcasters or other content providers and changes in technology may cause a
reduction in our advertising revenues and/or an increase in our operating
costs.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
television industry is highly competitive and this competition can draw viewers
and advertisers from our stations, which reduces our revenue or requires us to
pay more for programming, which increases our costs.&#160; We face intense competition from the
following:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">26</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='26',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bk.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:07 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h6 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;page-break-after:avoid;text-decoration:underline;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">New Technology and the subdivision of markets</font></u></h6>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cable
providers, direct broadcast satellite companies and telecommunication companies
are developing new </font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">technology
that allows them to transmit more channels on their existing equipment to
highly targeted audiences, reducing the cost of creating channels and
potentially leading to the division of the television industry into ever more
specialized niche markets.&#160; Competitors
who target programming to such sharply defined markets may gain an advantage
over us for television advertising revenues.&#160;
The decreased cost of creating channels may also encourage new competitors
to enter our markets and compete with us for advertising revenue.&#160; In addition, emerging technologies that will
allow viewers to digitally record, store and play back television programming
may decrease viewership of commercials as recorded by media measurement
services such as Neilsen Media Research and, as a result, lower our advertising
revenues.&#160; The broadcast and advertising
industries have agreed on a ratings standard that includes live viewing plus
viewers who watch a program within 72 hours of its original appearance.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h6 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;page-break-after:avoid;text-decoration:underline;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Types of competitors</font></u></h6>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We
also face competition from rivals that may have greater resources than we
have.&#160; These include:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; other local
free over-the-air broadcast television and radio stations;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">telecommunication companies;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; cable and
satellite system operators;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.25in;text-indent:-.5in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">print media providers such as newspapers, direct mail
and periodicals;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.25in;text-indent:-.5in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">internet providers; and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.25in;text-indent:-.5in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">competition from other emerging technologies.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h6 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;page-break-after:avoid;text-decoration:underline;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Deregulation</font></u></h6>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Telecommunications Act of 1996 and subsequent actions by the FCC have removed
some limits on station ownership, allowing telephone, cable and some other
companies to provide video services in competition with us.&#160; In addition, the FCC has reallocated a
portion of the spectrum for new services including fixed and mobile wireless
services and digital broadcast services.&#160;
As a result of these changes, new companies are able to enter our
markets and compete with us.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We could be adversely affected by labor disputes and other
union activity.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The cost of producing and
distributing entertainment programming has increased substantially in recent
years due to, among other things, the increasing demands of creative talent and
industry-wide collective bargaining agreements.&#160;
Although we generally purchase programming content from others rather
than produce it ourselves, our program suppliers engage the services of
writers, directors, actors and on-air and other talent, trade employees and
others, some of whom are subject to these collective bargaining agreements.&#160; If our program suppliers are unable to renew
expiring collective bargaining agreements, it is possible that the affected
unions could take action in the form of strikes or work stoppages, as
exemplified by the recently concluded Writers&#146; Guild of America strike.&#160; Failure to renew these agreements, higher
costs in connection with these agreements or a significant labor dispute could
adversely affect our business by causing delays in production that lead to
declining viewers, and reductions in the profit margins of our programming and
the amounts we can charge advertisers for time.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The commencement of the
Iraq War resulted in a decline in advertising revenues and negatively impacted
our operating results.&#160; Future conflicts
may have a similar effect.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The commencement of the
war in Iraq in 2002 resulted in a reduction of advertising revenues as a result
of uninterrupted news coverage and general economic uncertainty.&#160; During the first quarter of 2003, we
experienced $2.2 million in advertiser cancellations and preemptions, which
resulted in lower earnings than we would have experienced without this
disruption.&#160; If the United States becomes
engaged in similar conflicts in the future, there may be a similar adverse
effect on our results of operations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Unrelated
third parties may claim that we infringe on their rights based on the nature
and content of information posted on websites maintained by us.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We host internet services
that enable individuals to exchange information, generate content, comment on
our content, and engage in various online activities.&#160; The law relating to the liability of
providers of these online services for activities of their users is currently
unsettled both within the United States and internationally.&#160; While we monitor postings to such websites,
claims may be brought against us for defamation, negligence, copyright or
trademark infringement, unlawful activity, tort, including personal injury,
fraud, or other theories based on the nature and content of information that
may be posted online or generated by our users.&#160;
Our defense of such actions could be costly and involve significant time
and attention of our management and other resources.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 1B.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; UNRESOLVED STAFF
COMMENTS<a name="Item1b_UnresolvedStaffComments_230505"></a></font></b></h2>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">27</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='27',FILE='C:\JMS\pmarsha\08-2529-1\task2741368\2529-1-bk.htm',USER='pmarsha',CD='Feb 29 03:07 2008' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.52%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:0in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 2.</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="90%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:90.48%;">
  <h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PROPERTIES<a name="Properties_204405"></a></font></b></h2>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Generally,
each of our stations has facilities consisting of offices, studios and tower
sites.&#160; Transmitter and tower sites are
located to provide maximum signal coverage of our stations&#146; markets.&#160; We believe that all of our properties, both
owned and leased, are generally in good operating condition, subject to normal
wear and tear and are suitable and adequate for our current business
operations.&#160; The following is a summary
of our principal owned and leased real properties.&#160; All properties that are owned are included in
the broadcast segment.&#160; All properties
that are leased with the exception of our corporate headquarters are also
included in the broadcast segment.&#160;
Approximately 74,000 square feet of the leased office and studio building
below related to our corporate facilities.&#160;
We believe that no one property represents a material amount of the
total properties owned or leased.&#160; See <i>Item 1</i>. <i>Business,</i> for a
listing of our station locations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:1.92%;">

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="61%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:61.14%;">

  <p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:0in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 3.</font></b></p>

  <td width="90%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:90.48%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:0in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">LEGAL PROCEEDINGS<a name="LegalProceedings_204407"></a></font></b></p>
  </td>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We are
a party to lawsuits and claims from time to time in the ordinary course of
business.&#160; Actions currently pending are
in various preliminary stages and no judgments or decisions have been rendered
by hearing boards or courts in connection with such actions.&#160; After reviewing developments to date with
legal counsel, our management is of the opinion that the outcome of our pending
and threatened matters will not have a material adverse effect on our
consolidated balance sheets, consolidated statements of operations or
consolidated statements of cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.52%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:0in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 4.</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="90%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:90.48%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:0in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS<a name="SubmissionOfMattersToAVoteOfSecur_204409"></a></font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">No
matters were submitted to a vote of our shareholders during the fourth quarter
of 2007.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">28</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

 </tr>
